I am a passionate data analyst and statistician specializing in computational epidemiology, public health, oncology research, and Bayesian statistics. With a strong background in data management, analysis, and storytelling, I am dedicated to using data to uncover insights that drive impactful decisions.. Over the past few years, I’ve become very interested in research software, open source, reproducibility and data science practices in public sector.
In my current role, I leverage my skills to contribute to cutting-edge research and projects that address critical public health challenges. My passion for data extends beyond the workplace, as I continually seek to expand my knowledge and share it through publications, speaking engagements, and mentoring.
My Key Research Interests are:
I am currently pusruing my MSc in Epidemiology and Biostatistics at JOOUST, where I have finshed my coursework and designed a case study design to assess primary health facility financing for management of hypertension and diabestes in kisumu county. I look forward to registering for a PhD position to continue exploring the application of statistical methods in public health data, particularly in randomized clinical trails. Soon, I want to start developing R packages, I want to turn my thesis into a package, transparency, openness, and reproducibility.

text:

Sometimes I teach biostatistics courses at JOOUST school of health sciences (JOOUST), Kisumu. As a DataCamp certified data scientist, I also teach and help with R programming at the LERIS HUB.
I speak fluent English, Swahili and dholuo, and trying to learn French. Outside of work, I enjoy staying active and engaging in various sports. I have a deep appreciation for classical music, particularly Renaissance polyphony, and enjoy reading on topics ranging from Cold War history to Greek drama. Living with neuromyelitis optica has fueled my curiosity about complex health conditions and has driven me to understand them better through my research.

title: Nichodemus Amollo
text:
Hello!
I’m a data analyst and statistician passionate about public health data. I aim to use my expertise to drive impactful change, especially in resource-limited settings.
With over five years of experience, I’ve developed strong skills in data collection, analysis, and visualization. I’m proficient in RedCap and other EDC systems and have advanced expertise in R, SPSS, STATA, and SAS. My technical leadership and database management have been key in advancing public health projects.
In addition to my work, I serve as a part-time lecturer at JOOUST School of Health Sciences, where I teach statistics. I also conduct R programming workshops at LERIS HUB, helping researchers enhance their data analysis skills.
Outside work, I’m a fitness enthusiast who enjoys morning runs and nature walks. I’ve been following a keto diet for two years and practice OMAD (One Meal A Day), integrating wellness into my daily routine.

title: Global Temperature Changes
text:
This week’s Tidy Tuesday dataset focuses on global temperature changes over time. In this analysis, I explore the trends in global temperature increases and their potential implications on climate change.



# Load necessary libraries
library(tidyverse)

# Generate random data
set.seed(123)  # Set seed for reproducibility

# Create a sequence of years from 1900 to 2024
years <- seq(1900, 2024)

# Generate random temperature changes, simulating a gradual increase over time
temperature_change <- cumsum(rnorm(length(years), mean = 0.02, sd = 0.1))

# Combine the years and temperature changes into a data frame
temperature_data <- data.frame(year = years, temperature_change = temperature_change)

# Preview the data
head(temperature_data)

  year temperature_change
1 1900        -0.03604756
2 1901        -0.03906531
3 1902         0.13680552
4 1903         0.16385636
5 1904         0.19678513
6 1905         0.38829163



# Example plot
ggplot(temperature_data, aes(x = year, y = temperature_change)) +
  geom_line() +
  labs(title = "Global Temperature Changes Over Time", x = "Year", y = "Temperature Change (°C)")
